messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akao v Akasaka
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The soft metal ones are fairly rare.  The iron sukashi examples are seen more often, but signed ones aren t that common.  The ones that I ve seen
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The soft metal ones are fairly rare. The iron sukashi examples are seen more often, but signed ones aren't that common. The ones that I've seen generally have rather abstract, "hard edged" designs. The iron and the design sensibility are quite different from Akasaka work

FWIW I have one signed Echizen ju Akao Yoshitsugu shown here: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/hoan.htm fifth guard down.

Jim


Jim et all, are they that rare or does it just read like that. I have just recently picked up a nice Akao guard with Nihon Tosogu Bijutsukan Bunka Shiryoo Origami. I have added pics in the Rich T folder on the board titles akao1 and 2. The photo's do not do it justice.

http://tinyurl.com/ywzdx

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Akao v Akasaka
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, Interesting discussion here. I ve seen this piece on Benson s sight for a while and wondered about his attribution. I do not know much about Akao
messages.messageBody:
Richard,

Interesting discussion here. I've seen this piece on
Benson's sight for a while and wondered about his
attribution. I do not know much about Akao tsuba and
certainly couldn't have attributed it to Akao.

This may be a misnotion of entirely my own
construction, but I tend to think of Owari as more
solid surface plates where the inner sukashi design
flows out into the mimi.
On this one that Bob has, the fronds (or handlebar
moustache) that comes out of the Pauwlonia is
distinctly differentiated or slightly recessed from
the rimm.

Curran

This identical tsuba is pictured in the

of Echizen ju Akao. Unfortunately

some reason.

messages.subject: Akao v Akasaka
messages.msgSnippet: All, a while ago, Matt asked about the difference between Akao and Akasaka, I believe Rich S answered to some part about that, mentioning the tappered seppa
messages.messageBody:
All, a while ago, Matt asked about the difference between Akao and Akasaka, I believe Rich S answered to some part about that, mentioning the tappered seppa dai. Also distinct is the mimi which has a sharp roundness on it's outside wall and is known as Kittate on the inner wall ( Sharp as a cliff )There is also a terndancy for one typical hitsuana and the other that totally blends into the design of the tsuba. I know ther eis a term fo rthis but cannot fo rthe life of me remember it.

This I found in Tsuba, an aesthitic Study in regards to the Akao school.
The tsuba of this school; for the most part, whether made in Echizen of Iron plate ( I believe mine fits this category ) or in Edo of kawarigane plate, are better than the late works of the shoami school and the kinko. The early work of this school shows the superior ability above that of the majority of the contemporary workers of the period. The number of tsuba made by this school was few, and they were kakae-ko ( artist who worked exclusively for a daimyo family ). The general public very rarely had a chance to see the work of artists who were patronized by daimyo families. For this reason the style of the Akao school never had a chance to catch the fancy of the public. It was not imitated in great quantities as were the popular styles.

Jim et all, are they that rare or does it just read like that. I have just recently picked up a nice Akao guard with Nihon Tosogu Bijutsukan Bunka Shiryoo Origami. I have added pics in the Rich T folder on the board titles akao1 and 2. The photo's do not do it justice.

http://tinyurl.com/ywzdx

Cheers

Rich
